comment.body: Combining two obsolete technologies....  They hope for an addition, while I would argue it is a multiplication. As in  0.5 + 0.5 != 0.5 * 0.5  The weakest link in the chain is the most important in regards to security. Or in other words, piling shit doesn't make for a good tower. On the other hand, it's still an improvement over a three digit number on the back of the card.
@DElUSiON: magstripes were phased out in Europe more than a decade ago. The cards still contain them, but they are of no use. To make a payment, a chip is necessary.

As far as my understanding goes, swarm is more a competition for IPFS than for zeronet. Ethereum is a cool technology, but I'm still looking forward for a good use case for it. Most stuff I saw so far could be solved with easier and more robust solutions.
I wasn't even aware that bitmessage is still used. It stopped working for me a while ago. But namecoin still works nicely even though there doesn't seem to be a lot of development activity.
You can buy ICO tokens with ETH ;-)

ICO stands for initial coin offering. These tokens are like shares in a startup company. It's all the crace now in the blockchain community. But beware, it is more like crowdfunding, where the incentives are not tuned to deliver. Instead, the funders can run with the money. https://hoaxchain.com/ico1.html
@Jupadr: BitcoinUncensored has a few good episodes about Dash.

A turntable with a big horn and that you have to wind a spring would be cool. Full retro without electricity. But I guess these are hard to get.
@Krixano: Or good old C++

@TomasCW @Krixano: I have been developing C++ full time for the past 18 years. Sure it's not perfect, nothing is. But so far I didn't find anything better. The bad reputation it sometimes has, comes form horrible libraries such as the MFC. Also the standard improved tremendously over the years. It became much easier to write good code, and more difficult to write buggy code. With new language features templates have to be used less. Rust is interesting, I'll keep watching it.
@Happyrabbit: How can I generate fake likes in zerome?
This is one of the few things from google that I still use. Sad but true.
What are your experiences with BM? I really liked the idea when it came out. But after one message took half a year to be delivered, not so much any more. Did it improve over time?
When they can't surveil you easily, they abuse you to be their croud sourced mechanical turk to train their computer vision classifiers.
Isn't this the same with most development processes?

@caryoscelus:  Usually new debian packages land in the "unstable" channel. After two weeks they are merged into "testing". And only every two years a new "stable" is released. There are some exceptions to this, but I don't know the exact rules.

@caryoscelus: Wow, unstable? You must be brave. Do you run this on your main computer? Did you run into problems with regressions so far? Testing has a reputation of being much more stable than the name suggests, but I never heard of people actually running on unstable.
It should work if you leave the old battery inside, even if it is virtually dead. Unless ofc it exploded.
Bisq added in person trades a couple of months ago.

@caryoscelus: I use Bisq for bank transfer trades on a regular basis, but I didn't complete an in person bisq trade yet. Unfortunately the liquidity for CHF on bisq is quite low. And the in person offers I saw in the past were too far away.
@caryoscelus: The platform itself is very cool. The only downside for new users is that you need to already have some BTC for the deposit if you want to buy.
For a long time I thought if so many other people use a service and are ok with it, it would be probably be ok for me too. I can't remember when exactly I started to care more.
@Xan: Can you still call it a "man in the middle attack" if you voluntary invite the "man in the middle"?

That is a difficult topic. Of course it is good to clean up every wrongdoing, and it appears that Eppstein was a real monster. What the other people did and what they knew is hard to judge. I hope it will be researched by authorities, not by guesswork from people who know nothing but read a few headlines.
These days bare accusations in this field can ruin somebodies live. If the accusations are funded, then it is certainly just. But it can also be used as a weapon out of context. 
This happened to a friend of mine many years ago. When his wive separated, she did it in the worst possible way. Most damage was done by telling the divorce judge that he did inappropriate things with their daughter. Most friends can't imagine him doing something like this, but still some doubts always remain. His life was destroyed for many years.
